text: Solve this problem step by step.
End with 'DONE.' when you have a solution.
Question: A man lives on the 10th floor of an apartment building.
Every morning, he takes the elevator down to the ground floor to go to work.
When he returns in the evening, he takes the elevator to the 7th floor and then walks up the stairs for the remaining three floors to his apartment.
However, on rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way to the 10th floor.

Why does he do this? 

 Solution: 
<think>
Alright, so I have this puzzle here about a man living on the 10th floor of an apartment building.
Every morning, he takes the elevator down to the ground floor to go to work.
In the evening, when he returns, he takes the elevator up to the 7th floor and then walks up the stairs for the remaining three floors to his apartment.
But on rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way to the 10th floor.
The question is, why does he do this? Hmm, interesting.
Okay, let me try to break this down.
First, every morning, he goes from the 10th floor to the ground floor using the elevator.
So that's 10 floors down.
Then, in the evening, he takes the elevator up to the 7th floor and walks up three more floors.
So that's 7 floors up, then 3 floors by stairs.
On rainy days, instead of getting off at the 7th floor, he stays on the elevator all the way to the 10th floor.
Why would he do this on rainy days but not otherwise? Maybe it's about the elevator's behavior.
Wait, elevators usually don't go past the top floor, right? Or do they? Maybe in some buildings, the elevators can go beyond the top floor, but that seems unlikely.
Or perhaps there's something about the elevator's destination.
Maybe the elevator is programmed to stop at certain floors.
Wait, could it be that on rainy days, he doesn't want to get his shoes wet? So he takes the elevator all the way up to his apartment to avoid walking in the rain.
But in the evening, he takes the elevator only to the 7th floor, then walks up three floors.
Maybe because on rainy days, he doesn't want to walk the three floors, so he takes the elevator all the way.
But that seems a bit inconsistent with the other days.
Alternatively, maybe the elevator has a malfunction or a specific behavior.
For example, maybe the elevator stops at the 7th floor in the evening, but on rainy days, it goes all the way up.
Or perhaps the elevator has a maximum speed or time limit, so on rainy days, he takes it all the way to save time.
Wait, another angle: maybe the building's elevator has a limit on how high it can go.
So if it's raining, he needs to take the elevator all the way up, but on dry days, he can get off at the 7th floor.
Hmm, but why 7th floor specifically? Maybe because it's closer to his apartment in some way.
Or perhaps it's about the time the elevator takes.

Maybe the elevator is faster, so he saves time by taking it up to the 7th floor on dry days, but on rainy days, he needs to take it all the way because it's taking longer, or maybe he doesn't want to get wet walking.
Wait, another thought: maybe the elevator doesn't go above the 7th floor on dry days, so he can't take it higher.
But on rainy days, it does go higher.
That could be a reason.
So perhaps the elevator's operation changes depending on the weather.
That might make sense.
So when it's raining, the elevator is more willing to go higher, maybe because it's moving slower or has some system to prevent getting stuck.
Alternatively, maybe the man lives in a building where the elevator has a malfunction, like it only goes up to the 7th floor unless it's raining.
So on rainy days, it's fixed or has a different behavior.
Wait, maybe it's about the building's design.
If the building has an atrium or something, but that might be too complicated.
Another angle: maybe the man works in a place that's on the ground floor, so he goes all the way down in the morning.
In the evening, he goes up to the 7th floor and walks up three floors.
But on rainy days, he doesn't want to walk the three floors, so he takes the elevator all the way up.
That seems plausible.
So it's about avoiding walking in the rain.
But the question is why does he do this? So the reason is that on rainy days, he doesn't want to walk up the stairs, so he takes the elevator all the way to his apartment.
That makes sense because walking in the rain can be inconvenient or messy.

So, putting it all together, the man takes the elevator to the 7th floor on dry days because it's quicker, but on rainy days, he takes it all the way to his 10th floor to avoid getting wet walking up the stairs.

</think>

The man takes the elevator all the way to the 10th floor on rainy days to avoid walking up the stairs and getting wet.
On dry days, he stops at the 7th floor and walks up the remaining three floors because it's quicker and he doesn't need to worry about the weather.
